urn:contentItem:6FYJ-MYG3-RRKM-W3CM-00000-00Investigators from University of Sao Paulo Target Agroforestry (Management Intensity Does Not Affect the Ecological Indicators of Coffee Agroforestry Systems In Agricultural Landscapes of the Atlantic Forest Zone In Brazil)2025-06-03T00:00:00Z2025-09-16T06:41:40ZLexisNexisAGRICULTURE - AGROFORESTRYInvestigators from University of Sao Paulo Target Agroforestry (Management Intensity Does Not Affect the Ecological Indicators of Coffee Agroforestry Systems In Agricultural Landscapes of the Atlantic Forest Zone In Brazil)


2025 JUN 03 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Ecology Daily News -- Researchers detail new data in Agriculture - Agroforestry. According to news reporting from Piracicaba, Brazil, by NewsRx journalists, research stated, "Management interventions in agroforestry systems can reconcile ecological and productive outcomes while serving as part of forest restoration strategies. However, current knowledge on these impacts is still limited and controversial."


Financial supporters for this research include Fundao de Amparo Pesquisa do Estado de So Paulo, Institute of Ecological Research (IPE).
The news correspondents obtained a quote from the research from the University of Sao Paulo, "Here, we assessed the effects of management intensity on coffee production and ecological indicators in coffee agroforests, as well as their potential for landscape restoration. Specifically, we identified key management practices, assessed their effects on production and ecology, analyzed potential trade-offs, and compared agroforests with old-growth forests. We assessed 10 old agroforests (15-19 years), 7 young agroforests (5-6 years), and 3 old-growth forests in the Atlantic Forest. We identified management practices most associated with coffee production using Principal Component Analysis and assessed management effects through Multiple Linear Regression. Trade-offs were tested with Spearman's correlations, and ecological differences among systems were analyzed with ANOVA and Kruskal-Wallis tests. Higher management intensity-primarily through pruning, weeding, and natural fertilizers -significantly increased coffee production (p = 0.03) but did not impact ecological indicators. No trade-off was observed between production and ecological indicators. Overall, the management intensity and coffee production in the agroforestry were low. Old agroforests exhibited aboveground biomass levels comparable to old-growth forests. Despite relatively low coffee production, these agroforests enhance food security, income, and ecological benefits with minimal external inputs, offering a cost-effective strategy to landscape restoration."
According to the news reporters, the research concluded: "Our findings highlight that agroforestry with similar configurations but under low-intensity management can provide different benefits over time, depending on the combination of management practices."
This research has been peer-reviewed.
For more information on this research see: Management Intensity Does Not Affect the Ecological Indicators of Coffee Agroforestry Systems In Agricultural Landscapes of the Atlantic Forest Zone In Brazil. Agroforestry Systems, 2025;99(5). Agroforestry Systems can be contacted at: Springer, Van Godewijckstraat 30, 3311 Gz Dordrecht, Netherlands. (Springer - www.springer.com; Agroforestry Systems - www.springerlink.com/content/0167-4366/)
Our news journalists report that additional information may be obtained by contacting Vitoria Duarte Derisso, University of Sao Paulo, Dept. of Forestry Sciences, ESALQ, Piracicaba, Sp, Brazil. Additional authors for this research include Pedro H. S. Brancalion, Danilo R. A. Almeida, Paulo G. Molin, Edson Vidal, Ricardo Gomes Cesar, Aline Souza and Catherine Torres de Almeida.
The direct object identifier (DOI) for that additional information is: https://doi.org/10.1007/s10457-025-01201-z. This DOI is a link to an online electronic document that is either free or for purchase, and can be your direct source for a journal article and its citation.

urn:contentItem:6FT3-8413-RS9R-224T-00000-00Agriculture and Forestry University Researchers Describe Findings in Agroforestry (Assessing Carbon Sequestration in Agroforestry Systems in Churiya Range of Nepal)2025-05-13T00:00:00Z2025-09-16T06:41:40ZLexisNexisAGRICULTURE - AGROFORESTRYAgriculture and Forestry University Researchers Describe Findings in Agroforestry (Assessing Carbon Sequestration in Agroforestry Systems in Churiya Range of Nepal)


2025 MAY 13 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Agriculture Daily -- Current study results on agroforestry have been published. According to news reporting from Agriculture and Forestry University by NewsRx journalists, research stated, "Agroforestry is a system that combines household and community level food production ecosystem services along with income security. It has potential of carbon sequestration and puts a positive impact on balancing greenhouse gases."


The news reporters obtained a quote from the research from Agriculture and Forestry University: "The research was carried out to assess the variability of carbon stock under the agro-forestry systems in Churiya range at Rakshirang Rural Municipality of Makwanpur district of Nepal. Thirty households were sampled for this study; ten households from each of three different systems namely, Agrisilviculture, Silvopasture and Homegarden for data collection. Simple random sampling was used for the sample plot selection from the selected agroforestry systems for biomass and soil carbon estimation. Each system consisted of ten sample plots. Diameter and height of all trees with diameter at breast height greater than 10 cm were measured. The diameters of the trees were measured at standard height, i.e., diameter at breast height. Above ground biomass, below ground biomass and soil organic carbon were summed to determine the total carbon stock in the agroforestry systems. Collected data were analyzed through tabular analysis, and volume and biomass estimation of the trees. Total carbon stock was found higher in Silvopasture system (32.41t/ha), 28.58 t/ha in Agrisilviculture system and 30.71 t/ha in Homegarden system."
According to the news editors, the research concluded: "Results have shown the potentiality of agroforestry systems for carbon sequestration. Such systems need to be promoted for their efforts by encouraging them with some subsidized input support, financial support or some capacity building trainings by the government."
For more information on this research see: Assessing Carbon Sequestration in Agroforestry Systems in Churiya Range of Nepal. Turkish Journal of Agriculture: Food Science and Technology, 2025,13(4):842-848. (Turkish Journal of Agriculture: Food Science and Technology - http://agrifoodscience.com/index.php/TURJAF/index). The publisher for Turkish Journal of Agriculture: Food Science and Technology is Turkish Science and Technology Publishing (TURSTEP).
A free version of this journal article is available at https://doi.org/10.24925/turjaf.v13i4.842-848.5826.
Our news journalists report that more information may be obtained by contacting Lilu Kumari Magar, Faculty of Forestry, Agriculture and Forestry University, Hetauda, Nepal. Additional authors for this research include Gandhiv Kafle.
Keywords for this news article include: Agriculture and Forestry University, Agriculture, Agroforestry, Asia, Nepal.

urn:contentItem:6G06-JBR3-RRHV-X4RM-00000-00Studies from French Agricultural Research Center for International Development (CIRAD) Describe New Findings in Agroforestry (Maximizing Tree Diversity In Cocoa Agroforestry: Taking Advantage of Planted, Spontaneous, and Remnant Trees)2025-06-06T00:00:00Z2025-09-16T06:41:40ZLexisNexisAGRICULTURE - AGROFORESTRYStudies from French Agricultural Research Center for International Development (CIRAD) Describe New Findings in Agroforestry (Maximizing Tree Diversity In Cocoa Agroforestry: Taking Advantage of Planted, Spontaneous, and Remnant Trees)


2025 JUN 06 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Food Daily News -- Data detailed on Agriculture - Agroforestry have been presented. According to news reporting originating in Montpellier, France, by NewsRx journalists, research stated, "Cocoa production stands as the primary driver of biodiversity loss in West Africa. In response to this challenge, agroforestry emerges as a promising solution to restore tree cover and preserve biodiversity in agricultural landscapes."


Funders for this research include European Commission Joint Research Centre, European DeSIRA Initiative, French Development Agency.
The news reporters obtained a quote from the research from French Agricultural Research Center for International Development (CIRAD), "Despite distributions of millions of trees to farmers through various sustainability initiatives, survival rates of planted trees have been disappointing in cocoa fields. However, many non-planted trees currently exist in cocoa fields, including trees from spontaneous regeneration and remnants from previous forests. Our study aims to explore the origins of tree biodiversity in current Ivorian cocoa fields and identify the key socio-environmental determinants. Across 150 cocoa fields, 9939 trees were botanically identified, allowing estimation of diversity and complementarity levels between planted, spontaneous, and remnant cohorts, linked to socio-environmental variables within a Bayesian modelling framework. Results revealed that remnant and spontaneous trees exhibited much greater diversity than planted trees, with the latter showing important complementarity with the other cohorts. Moreover, the diversity of each tree cohort was influenced by a distinct set of environmental factors such as climate and soil composition, highlighting the need to consider the unique history and location of each cocoa field to support agroforestry development. Effective biodiversity maximisation thus relies on preserving remnant trees, vital sources of propagules for natural regeneration, while carefully selecting spontaneous trees and complementary introducing planted trees."
According to the news reporters, the research concluded: "Furthermore, recognizing the farmer's identity as a key factor shaping observed biodiversity underscores the importance of raising awareness among farmers and offering tree recognition training, particularly for young trees."
This research has been peer-reviewed.
For more information on this research see: Maximizing Tree Diversity In Cocoa Agroforestry: Taking Advantage of Planted, Spontaneous, and Remnant Trees. Agroforestry Systems, 2025;99(5). Agroforestry Systems can be contacted at: Springer, Van Godewijckstraat 30, 3311 Gz Dordrecht, Netherlands. (Springer - www.springer.com; Agroforestry Systems - www.springerlink.com/content/0167-4366/)
Our news correspondents report that additional information may be obtained by contacting Bruno Herault, French Agricultural Research Center for International Development (CIRAD), Upr Forets & Soc, Montpellier, France. Additional authors for this research include Isaac Kouame Konan, Anny E. N'Guessan, Justin K. N'dja, Marie R. Dago, Aime Kouassi, Raphael Aussenac, Soulemane Traore, Stephane Guei and Patrick Jagoret.

urn:contentItem:6FP3-N0F3-RXTH-R4TH-00000-00Reports Outline Agroforestry Findings from Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam (Potential Multifaceted Agroforestry Impacts On Farming Household's Livelihoods In Viet Nam: Need To Account for Agroforestry Type, Magnitude and Maturity for Non-biased ...)2025-04-29T00:00:00Z2025-09-16T06:41:40ZLexisNexisAGRICULTURE - AGROFORESTRYReports Outline Agroforestry Findings from Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam (Potential Multifaceted Agroforestry Impacts On Farming Household's Livelihoods In Viet Nam: Need To Account for Agroforestry Type, Magnitude and Maturity for Non-biased ...)


2025 APR 29 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Food Daily News -- New research on Agriculture - Agroforestry is the subject of a report. According to news reporting originating from Amsterdam, Netherlands, by NewsRx correspondents, research stated, "Agroforestry is widely recommended in the mountainous areas of Southeast Asia to improve farmers' livelihoods and reverse current land degradation trends. However, studies of the impacts of adoption of agroforestry practices on smallholder farmer livelihoods are limited to field-scale assessments and landscape potential."


Financial supporters for this research include Swedish Research Council Formas, Consortium of International Agricultural Research Centers, Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research, Swedish Research Council.
Our news editors obtained a quote from the research from Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam, "In this paper, we assess the difference in terms of farming system performance between agroforestry adopters and non-adopters in northwest Viet Nam using propensity score matching (PSM) calculating the average treatment (agroforestry adoption) effect on the treated (adopters) on core economic, environmental, and social indicators. The results of the PSM indicate an increase in revenues of about 8 million VND ha-1 yr-1 (about 325$) per household when adopting agroforestry, but a counterintuitive outcome regarding erosion. This outcome is likely due to an improperly selected farmer control group, which is located on less erosion-prone land, as well as the presence of immature trees in agroforestry systems, whose canopies have not yet contributed to reducing erosion. A typology of adopters was produced and revealed a wide diversity of agroforestry adoption pathways across the population, which may have blurred the results of the PSM. Six farming household types were obtained ranging from 'Off-farm income-dependent farmers' with low proportion of agroforestry to 'Specialists mixed agroforesters' with higher proportion of agroforestry practices on their farm and different levels of input intensity in their farming systems. This typology highlights the need for greater context awareness in farming system research and proper control of the agroforestry type, the proportion of agroforestry in the farming systems, and the maturity of the agroforestry system."
According to the news editors, the research concluded: "This will help to better capture the real-life, farm-scale impacts of agroforestry practices."
This research has been peer-reviewed.
For more information on this research see: Potential Multifaceted Agroforestry Impacts On Farming Household's Livelihoods In Viet Nam: Need To Account for Agroforestry Type, Magnitude and Maturity for Non-biased Evaluation. Agroforestry Systems, 2025;99(4). Agroforestry Systems can be contacted at: Springer, Van Godewijckstraat 30, 3311 Gz Dordrecht, Netherlands. (Springer - www.springer.com; Agroforestry Systems - www.springerlink.com/content/0167-4366/)
The news editors report that additional information may be obtained by contacting Pierre Chopin, Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam, Inst Environm Studies Ivm, Environm Geog Grp, Nl-1081HV Amsterdam, Netherlands. Additional authors for this research include Thi Thanh Thuong Dang, Paolo Sckokai, Kai Mausch, Mai Phuong Nguyen, Nguyen La, Ingrid Oeborn and Sigrun Dahlin.

urn:contentItem:6GRG-9T43-RXM9-3168-00000-00Sesc Thermas hosts samba concert, puppet show and workshop on Amazonian coffee2025-09-13T00:00:00Z2025-09-16T06:41:40ZLexisNexisSesc Thermas hosts samba concert, puppet show and workshop on Amazonian coffee


A samba show, children's theater, experiences and workshops make up an agenda full of free activities this weekend at Sesc Thermas in Presidente Prudente. Among the highlights are the sensory workshop on Amazonian coffee and the agroforestry course, dedicated to growing Brazil's most beloved bean.


The program starts this Saturday at 9:30 a.m. with the course Agroforestry Systems with a Focus on Coffee, given by Anderson Arcanjoleto and Angélica Facirolli, from Sítio Santa Terra. The aim is to present the principles of agroforestry systems, highlighting agroecological coffee production, in an experience that combines theory and practice. Registration is free and can be done online, for people aged 14 and over.
At 10.30am, in the Technology and Arts Space, educator Leandro Mariano leads the workshop Exploring Artworks and Museums with Google Arts & Culture, also available on Sunday, which presents Google's digital platform, allowing access to cultural collections from all over the world, such as works of art and historical documents.
In the afternoon, at 2:30 p.m., barista Deborah Veneziano leads the workshop Café com Sentido: Cultura, Natureza e Percepção (Coffee with Sense: Culture, Nature and Perception), which offers a sensory experience with Amazonian coffee produced in agroforestry systems in Rondônia. The activity invites the public to explore flavors, aromas and memories through the five senses. It is aimed at people over 16 years old and tickets can be collected at the venue 30 minutes before the start.
Closing Saturday, at 4pm, the Prudentine group Fina Estampa takes to the stage in the Social Area, with a repertoire of choro and samba. Formed in 2008 on the initiative of multi-instrumentalist Luiz Ramos, and today made up of him, Thaise Torres, Inácio Bratifisch, Wanderley Abelo and Claudinho, the quintet plays classics by Noel Rosa, Cartola, Pixinguinha, Ivone Lara, Paulinho da Viola, among other well-known names.
As well as performing at events and at regional nightclubs, the group has performed shows such as "Sambas de Gafieira I and II". It was the opening act at shows by Alceu Valença, Demônios da Garoa and renowned pianist Eudóxia de Barros - all in Presidente Prudente. He also took part in four editions of Virada Cultural Paulista, as well as Virada Prudente 2021, through the Aldir Blanc Law.
Sunday
The Sesc Thermas program continues on Sunday at 10:30 am with the Agroforestry for Small Farmers workshop, now aimed at children aged 3 to 12. Anderson Arcanjoleto and Angélica Facirolli lead the activity, which takes place in the Sesc vegetable garden, combining storytelling, illustrations and planting practices to awaken ecological awareness in a playful and educational way. Tickets must be collected at the venue 30 minutes before the start.
At 2:30 p.m., artist Vitor Dantas will lead the workshop Drawing - Sometimes I see dragons in the clouds, inspired by Jorge Luis Borges' "The Book of Imaginary Beings". Using paper and ink, participants are invited to transform stains, outlines and colors into new creatures and narratives, exploring the collective imagination.
At 4pm, Cia. Articularte presents the show "Menino Coragem" (Courageous Boy) in the Social Area. The play tells the story of Zaki and Janaína, two Afro-Brazilian children who, after losing their parents, embark on adventures full of folkloric beings and fantastic creatures, accompanied by their amusing pet, Uí. The puppet show values ancestry and cultural identity, conveying messages of courage, resilience and affection in a touching experience for children and adults alike.

urn:contentItem:6GRP-S463-RY9R-S2CR-00000-00Indonesia aims to create one million jobs in forestry2025-09-15T00:00:00Z2025-09-16T06:41:40ZLexisNexisIndonesia aims to create one million jobs in forestrySeeNews

Sep 11, 2025

Indonesian Minister of Manpower Yassierli announced the government's plans to create at least one million jobs in forestry over the next three to four years. Green professions and the introduction of agroforestry practices will form the basis for growth, TV BRICS reports.

According to him, achieving this goal will require the joint efforts of all stakeholders, including the training of qualified personnel. One of the key areas will be training in agroforestry, social forestry and the application of modern technologies in the forestry and agricultural sectors.

According to Antara News, Yassierli emphasised that agroforestry opens up significant potential for employment, while turning forests into sources of food, energy and water, which is in line with President Prabowo Subianto's strategic vision.

The training programme is now in its third phase and has 388 participants. The Ministry plans to expand the project's ecosystem, create business models and develop product processing.

Earlier, it was reported that Kazakhstan and South Korea are set to deepen cooperation in forestry.

urn:contentItem:6FVK-1J23-S023-63VY-00000-00Studies from Universitas Lampung Describe New Findings in Agroforestry (Correlation of Knowledge And Community Participation in Land Conservation-based Agroforestry: A Case Study in Tanjung Agung Village, Lampung)2025-05-20T00:00:00Z2025-09-16T06:41:40ZLexisNexisAGRICULTURE - AGROFORESTRYStudies from Universitas Lampung Describe New Findings in Agroforestry (Correlation of Knowledge And Community Participation in Land Conservation-based Agroforestry: A Case Study in Tanjung Agung Village, Lampung)


2025 MAY 20 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Agriculture Daily -- Investigators discuss new findings in agroforestry. According to news reporting originating from the Universitas Lampung by NewsRx correspondents, research stated, "The conversion of forest land to agriculture has affected the ecosystem in the upstream area of Way Betung Watershed, including Tanjung Agung Village."


The news editors obtained a quote from the research from Universitas Lampung: "This study aims to analyze the relationship between knowledge, community participation, and agroforestry land conservation. The study was conducted on 30 respondents using a structured questionnaire, the results of which were analyzed using the Spearman Rank correlation test. The results showed that the level of community knowledge was in the moderate category (mean score 2.3), while the level of participation was high (mean score 3.7). The level of agroforestry land conservation was recorded in the moderate to high category (mean score 3.3). Correlation analysis showed a significant relationship between knowledge and community participation (r = 0.414, p = 0.023) with sufficient closeness, but no significant relationship was found between knowledge and land conservation (r = 0.219, p = 0.245) or participation and land conservation (r = 0.291, p = 0.119). This study highlights that increasing community participation has great potential to support the success of agroforestry conservation, although the contribution of knowledge needs to be strengthened."
According to the news editors, the research concluded: "The novelty of this research lies in the in-depth analysis of the level of relationship between social variables in supporting agroforestry-based conservation in the strategic upstream area of the Way Betung Watershed."
For more information on this research see: Correlation of Knowledge And Community Participation in Land Conservation-based Agroforestry: A Case Study in Tanjung Agung Village, Lampung. Jurnal Belantara, 2025,8(2). The publisher for Jurnal Belantara is Forestry Study Program University of Mataram.
A free version of this journal article is available at https://doi.org/10.29303/jbl.v8i2.1117.
Our news journalists report that additional information may be obtained by contacting Kheynad, Universitas Lampung.
Keywords for this news article include: Universitas Lampung, Agriculture, Agroforestry.

urn:contentItem:6G12-F363-RSMF-R4B5-00000-00Research Results from International Institute of Tropical Agriculture (IITA) Update Understanding of Agroforestry (Soil fertility improvement in agroforestry after 30 years of silvopasture on ferric lixisols within the Guinea Savanna ecology of ...)2025-06-10T00:00:00Z2025-09-16T06:41:40ZLexisNexisAGRICULTURE - AGROFORESTRYResearch Results from International Institute of Tropical Agriculture (IITA) Update Understanding of Agroforestry (Soil fertility improvement in agroforestry after 30 years of silvopasture on ferric lixisols within the Guinea Savanna ecology of ...)


2025 JUN 10 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Agriculture Daily -- Investigators discuss new findings in agroforestry. According to news originating from Ibadan, Nigeria, by NewsRx editors, the research stated, "This research examines the sustained enhancement of soil fertility in the Guinea Savanna of Nigeria, by comparing silvopasture and cropland systems on ferric lixisols, soils known for low fertility and nutrient retention. The research addresses the pressing issue of soil degradation in Fasola area of Oyo State, Nigeria."


Our news correspondents obtained a quote from the research from International Institute of Tropical Agriculture (IITA): "A silvopastural system established over three decades was assessed and compared with conventional arable land using a fixed grid sampling technique across 30 sampling locations for each land-use system within a 1000 ha. The assessment focused on the topsoil layer of 0-20 cm depth. The soil samples were analyzed for pH, organic carbon content, total nitrogen, available phosphorus, and other exchangeable cations and the soil micronutrients, using wet chemistry standard procedures. The results showed that the silvopastural system considerably enhanced soil fertility. Organic carbon increased by 290 %, total nitrogen by 183 %, and available phosphorus by 150 % compared to cropland soils. Additionally, concentrations of exchangeable cations, such as calcium (325 % increase), magnesium (400 % increase), and potassium (300 % increase), were substantially higher in silvopasture systems. Micronutrient levels, including zinc, copper, iron, and manganese, also significantly increased."
According to the news reporters, the research concluded: "The results show that silvopastural system provides a feasible technique for long-term soil fertility increases, delivering essential advantages for sustainable agriculture and soil management in the Guinea Savanna ecology. Silvopastoral system, through nitrogen cycling and water retention, may aid in the rejuvenation of degraded soils and improve crop productivity in nutrient-depleted soils."
For more information on this research see: Soil fertility improvement in agroforestry after 30 years of silvopasture on ferric lixisols within the Guinea Savanna ecology of Nigeria. Trees, Forests and People, 2025,20():100847. The publisher for Trees, Forests and People is Elsevier.
A free version of this journal article is available at https://doi.org/10.1016/j.tfp.2025.100847.
Our news editors report that more information may be obtained by contacting Samuel A. Mesele, International Institute of Tropical Agriculture (IITA), Ibadan, Nigeria. Additional authors for this research include Festus O. Adelana, Mouna Mechri.
Keywords for this news article include: International Institute of Tropical Agriculture (IITA), Ibadan, Nigeria, Africa, Agriculture, Agroforestry, Ecology.

urn:contentItem:6FPH-KT43-RW9Y-54CM-00000-00Faculty of Agriculture Researchers Advance Knowledge in Agroforestry (Perception of former illegal logger to agroforestry in Tetelan land of Meru Betiri National Park, Indonesia)2025-05-01T00:00:00Z2025-09-16T06:41:40ZLexisNexisAGRICULTURE - AGROFORESTRYFaculty of Agriculture Researchers Advance Knowledge in Agroforestry (Perception of former illegal logger to agroforestry in Tetelan land of Meru Betiri National Park, Indonesia)


2025 MAY 01 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at NewsRx Life Science Daily -- New research on agroforestry is the subject of a new report. According to news reporting from the Faculty of Agriculture by NewsRx journalists, research stated, "A sustainable livelihood program for former illegal loggers implemented by agriculture cultivation in rehabilitation zones or 'Tetelan' land. Then, the agroforestry system should be applied to restore the function of forests and generate economic value."


Our news editors obtained a quote from the research from Faculty of Agriculture: "The research aims to examine the perceptions of former illegal loggers and the factors that influence the application of agroforestry on 'tetelan' land. The research was conducted in Sanenrejo Village and Andongrejo Village, Tempurejo District, Jember Regency, East Java as buffer villages of the Meru Betiri National Park (MBNP). The research data used has cross-sectional characteristics. The data were measured using the Likert scale and analyzed using descriptive quantitative methods, followed by the Chi-square method to determine the effect of the relationship between variables. Perception of former illegal loggers of agroforestry in 'tetelan' land is in a good category. This means that efforts to implement an agroforestry system in 'Tetelan' land to restore forest function have a high chance of success. At the same time, the factors that significantly influence the application of agroforestry are education and income."
According to the news editors, the research concluded: "Individual approach efforts should target ex-illegal logger farmers with an elementary school education and low income (between IDR 300,000-IDR 6,200,000)."
For more information on this research see: Perception of former illegal logger to agroforestry in Tetelan land of Meru Betiri National Park, Indonesia. AGROMIX, 2025,16(1). The publisher for AGROMIX is Faculty of Agriculture, University of Yudharta Pasuruan.
A free version of this journal article is available at https://doi.org/10.35891/agx.v16i1.6000.
Our news journalists report that additional information may be obtained by contacting Khusnatul Khomsah, Agribusiness Department, Faculty of Agriculture, Trunojoyo University of Madura, Jl Raya Telang PO BOX 2 Kamal, Bangkalan, Indonesia. Additional authors for this research include Ihsannudin, Sukmo Pinuji, Lennny Luthfiyah.
Keywords for this news article include: Faculty of Agriculture, Agriculture, Agroforestry, National Parks.

urn:contentItem:6FX2-VG63-RXB0-F482-00000-00Research on Agroforestry Described by a Researcher at Department of Plant Science (Nutrient Composition and Antinutritional Evaluation of Selected Wild Edible Plants Grown in Agroforestry of Simada District, Ethiopia)2025-05-27T00:00:00Z2025-09-16T06:41:40ZLexisNexisAGRICULTURE - AGROFORESTRYResearch on Agroforestry Described by a Researcher at Department of Plant Science (Nutrient Composition and Antinutritional Evaluation of Selected Wild Edible Plants Grown in Agroforestry of Simada District, Ethiopia)


2025 MAY 27 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Agriculture Daily -- New study results on agroforestry have been published. According to news originating from the Department of Plant Science by NewsRx correspondents, research stated, "This investigation was carried out to evaluate the nutrient composition and antinutritional factors of five wild edible fruits Embelia schimperi, Cordia africana, Ficus vasta, Mimusops kummel, and Syzygium guineense. Proximate composition parameters (moisture, ash, crude fiber, crude fat, and crude protein) and antinutritional factors were evaluated using methods of the Association of Official Analytical Chemists and mineral analysis using the atomic absorption spectroscopy method."


Our news editors obtained a quote from the research from Department of Plant Science: "Microsoft Excel and Statistical Package for Social Sciences (SPSS Version 20) were used to analyze the data. Among the five wild edible fruit species, Embelia schimperi and Cordia africana had the highest fiber content (18±0.03 g/100 g) and high protein content (8.7±0.03 g/100 g), respectively. Syzygium guineense had the highest amount of moisture (16.3±0.001 g/100 g), energy (320.58±0.03 kcal/100 g), and carbohydrate content (76.72 g/100 g). Embelia schimperi was found to have the highest saponin content (2.1 mg/100 g). Oxalate content ranged from 0.46 mg/100 g in Syzygium guineense to 1.7 mg/100 g in Cordia africana. Mineral analysis showed that Ficus vasta had the highest Ca content (1015 mg/100 g), whereas the highest Zn content (38.6 mg/100 g) was investigated in Embelia schimperi."
According to the news editors, the research concluded: "According to their recommended proximate and mineral contribution to daily nutrient requirements in humans, Embelia schimperi, Cordia africana, Ficus vasta, Mimusops kummel, and Syzygium guineense are sound in their dietary composition and in combating hunger especially in developing countries. More studies are vital to assess the nutritional composition and antinutritional quality of these wild edible plants and encourage farmers to cultivate in the agroforestry system."
For more information on this research see: Nutrient Composition and Antinutritional Evaluation of Selected Wild Edible Plants Grown in Agroforestry of Simada District, Ethiopia. The Scientific World Journal, 2025,2025. (The Scientific World Journal - https://www.hindawi.com/journals/tswj/). The publisher for The Scientific World Journal is Wiley.
A free version of this journal article is available at https://doi.org/10.1155/tswj/3545895.
Our news journalists report that additional information may be obtained by contacting Kindye Belaye Wassie, Department of Plant Science.
Keywords for this news article include: Department of Plant Science, Agriculture, Agroforestry.

urn:contentItem:6FSW-8S43-RVFP-23DH-00000-00Helmholtz Centre for Environmental Research - UFZ Reports Findings in Agroforestry (Rethinking knowledge systems for agroforestry: Insights from the mental models of cacao farmers in Colombia)2025-05-12T00:00:00Z2025-09-16T06:41:40ZLexisNexisAGRICULTURE - AGROFORESTRYHelmholtz Centre for Environmental Research - UFZ Reports Findings in Agroforestry (Rethinking knowledge systems for agroforestry: Insights from the mental models of cacao farmers in Colombia)


2025 MAY 12 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Agriculture Daily -- New research on Agriculture - Agroforestry is the subject of a report. According to news reporting originating from Leipzig, Germany, by NewsRx correspondents, research stated, "Agroforestry is a sustainable land-use strategy that requires better integration of diverse knowledge systems. This paper examines how formal knowledge systems for cacao agroforestry systems in Colombia are structured, and how farmers understand and manage these systems."


Financial supporters for this research include International Climate Initiative, Helmholtz-Zentrum fur Umweltforschung GmbH - UFZ.
Our news editors obtained a quote from the research from Helmholtz Centre for Environmental Research - UFZ, "We interviewed 42 actors involved in knowledge production and dissemination and worked with 18 farmers to create mental maps of their management practices. Our findings show that formal knowledge systems remain predominantly top-down and scientific-based, despite increasing recognition of local knowledge. Farmers' mental models reflect this, showing reliance on external advice and simplified cause-and-effect thinking. When theoretically pooling farmers' perspectives, we observe a more comprehensive understanding of agroforestry, suggesting that social learning can strengthen their independence and adaptive capacity."
According to the news editors, the research concluded: "Moreover, farm management is shaped by context-dependent variables such as climate seasonality and market access, thus highlighting the importance of integrating farmers' experiential knowledge into agroforestry design and dissemination for more sustainable, context-sensitive decision-making."
This research has been peer-reviewed.
For more information on this research see: Rethinking knowledge systems for agroforestry: Insights from the mental models of cacao farmers in Colombia. Ambio, 2025. Ambio can be contacted at: Springer, Van Godewijckstraat 30, 3311 Gz Dordrecht, Netherlands. (Springer - www.springer.com; Ambio - www.springerlink.com/content/0044-7447/)
The news editors report that additional information may be obtained by contacting Tatiana Rodriguez, Dept. of Environmental Politics, Helmholtz Centre for Environmental Research - UFZ, Permoserstraße 15, 04318, Leipzig, Germany. Additional authors for this research include Michelle Bonatti, Katharina Lohr and Stefan Sieber.
The direct object identifier (DOI) for that additional information is: https://doi.org/10.1007/s13280-025-02189-7. This DOI is a link to an online electronic document that is either free or for purchase, and can be your direct source for a journal article and its citation.
Publisher contact information for the journal Ambio is: Springer, Van Godewijckstraat 30, 3311 Gz Dordrecht, Netherlands.

urn:contentItem:6GPW-PYJ3-RRHR-841T-00000-00Cortile Scientific Limited Details Findings in Agriculture (Data on greenhouse gas fluxes from smallholder cropping systems in Upper Eastern Kenya)2025-09-11T00:00:00Z2025-09-16T06:41:40ZLexisNexisAGRICULTURECortile Scientific Limited Details Findings in Agriculture (Data on greenhouse gas fluxes from smallholder cropping systems in Upper Eastern Kenya)


2025 SEP 11 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Climate Change Daily News -- New research on Agriculture is the subject of a report. According to news reporting originating from Nairobi, Kenya, by NewsRx correspondents, research stated, "This dataset presents greenhouse gas (GHG) fluxes-carbon dioxide (CO ), methane (CH ), and nitrous oxide (N O) measurements collected from smallholder cropping systems in Chuka, Upper Eastern Kenya. The study aimed to assess the effects of different cropping systems on soil GHG fluxes, as described in a related study (Lemarpe et al., 2023)."


Our news editors obtained a quote from the research from Cortile Scientific Limited, "Data were collected over two cropping seasons from five cropping systems: sole maize, maize-bean intercrop, agroforestry, banana and coffee replicated three times. The study used static chambers to measure GHG fluxes, which were then analyzed using gas chromatography. The dataset also consists of soil physicochemical parameters (bulk density, total nitrogen, organic carbon, and pH), soil moisture, rainfall, and crop yield data for maize and beans."
According to the news editors, the research concluded: "This dataset offers findings on how agricultural practices affect GHG emissions and the possibility of smallholder cropping systems, such as agroforestry, to act as nature-based solutions for climate change mitigation."
For more information on this research see: Data on greenhouse gas fluxes from smallholder cropping systems in Upper Eastern Kenya. Data In Brief, 2025;62:111955.
The news editors report that additional information may be obtained by contacting Shaankua E. Lemarpe, Cortile Scientific Limited, PO Box 34991, 00100, Nairobi, Kenya. Additional authors for this research include Collins M. Musafiri, Milka N. Kiboi and Felix K. Ngetich.

urn:contentItem:6GPD-0443-RV7W-T08K-00000-00Opportunity for the countryside, by Mariano Marzo2025-09-08T00:00:00Z2025-09-16T06:41:40ZLexisNexisOpportunity for the countryside, by Mariano Marzo


The terrible fires that have ravaged Spain this summer have once again highlighted the neglect and lack of care of our forests. Experts and, above all, the dwindling population of the places that have been burned attribute the voracity of the flames to the accumulation of woody debris, leaves and undergrowth, an excess of organic matter that has made many of these fires uncontrollable.


Behind this situation is the unstoppable process of depopulation of the Spanish countryside. The lack of economic incentives, the scarce possibilities of obtaining a good job or creating profitable companies pushes young people towards the big cities. There are fewer and fewer people and older people, so traditional activities such as the use of biomass generated by forests and agricultural activity are being abandoned.
Our country has an obligation to generate opportunities for these young people and, at the same time, protect our forests more effectively. One of the main alternatives is to use agroforestry biomass to produce renewable energy, an activity that would create local employment in the collection, transport and pre-treatment of this waste and would also reduce the presence of vegetable fuel in the countryside and, therefore, the risk of fire. It is estimated that the removal of accumulated vegetation in high-risk areas could reduce the area burned by up to 60%.
Agroforestry biomass is already used to generate heat and electricity, but now it can also be used to produce biogas, biomethane and, above all, renewable fuels for transport. The magic of chemistry makes it possible to transform branches and leaves, but also crop residues, agro-industrial waste and used cooking oils, into liquid fuels that are compatible with current combustion engines, so they will be key to reducing CO2 emissions from cars, trucks, planes and ships.
Agroforestry biomass has huge growth potential in Spain
Spain is one of the countries with the largest forest and agricultural area in Europe, so it has abundant raw material to lead the production of renewable gases and fuels. However, the reality is that our country only uses a third of the biomass generated by its forests. This fact confirms that we have to start actively managing these natural spaces, including their cleaning, but also the reuse of forest surpluses.
It is time for our authorities to give a real boost to the energy recovery of agroforestry biomass, which has enormous growth potential in Spain. This sector will not only encourage the maintenance of forests, but will also contribute to the economic development of many rural areas threatened by depopulation, whose future only seems to interest society now when their forests are burned every summer.

urn:contentItem:6FPR-JXT3-RSMG-R1C6-00000-00Reports on Agroforestry Findings from University of Seville Provide New Insights (First Uass Drift Curves for Agroforestry Scenarios In Spain)2025-05-02T00:00:00Z2025-09-16T06:41:40ZLexisNexisAGRICULTURE - AGROFORESTRYReports on Agroforestry Findings from University of Seville Provide New Insights (First Uass Drift Curves for Agroforestry Scenarios In Spain)


2025 MAY 02 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Food Daily News -- Current study results on Agriculture - Agroforestry have been published. According to news reporting originating in Seville, Spain, by NewsRx journalists, research stated, "Unmanned aerial spraying systems (UASS) allow the agricultural sector to execute precision spraying of plant protection products (PPPs). However, scientific knowledge regarding the spray drift generated by these aerial spraying systems is needed to facilitate their integration into European agriculture."


Financial supporters for this research include OG PhytoDron (Validation and Safety of Drone Applications in the Agroforestry Environment), Spanish Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food & European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development (EAFRD).
The news reporters obtained a quote from the research from the University of Seville, "Currently, UASS spray drift models have not been developed. This study aims to characterize sedimenting spray drift curves for UASS in 3D crops and compare them with reference drift models used in the environmental risk assessment of PPPs in Europe under Regulation (EC) No 1107/2009. To accomplish this, drift trials were conducted in typical agroforestry scenarios in Spain, including super high-density olive orchards, grapevines, and pine tree plantations. UASSs generated more drift than the terrestrial reference drift models in grapevine trials. Conversely, in super highdensity olive orchards, the drift generated by UASSs was significantly reduced compared to both terrestrial and aerial reference models. For pine trees, a reliable UASS sedimenting drift curve could not be established. UASSs present a promising tool for agricultural applications, though with certain limitations. The similarity in drift between UASSs and the aerial reference model in grapevines may result from a wider-than-necessary swath width. Future developments of UASS should consider implementing variable-width spraying to match the target plant size. In forestry crops, the high spraying altitude complicated the development of a reliable sedimenting drift curve under the conditions of this study."
According to the news reporters, the research concluded: "Further research is needed to optimize UASS use in various agricultural settings."
This research has been peer-reviewed.
For more information on this research see: First Uass Drift Curves for Agroforestry Scenarios In Spain. Crop Protection, 2025;191. Crop Protection can be contacted at: Elsevier Sci Ltd, 125 London Wall, London, England. (Elsevier - www.elsevier.com; Crop Protection - www.journals.elsevier.com/crop-protection/)
Our news correspondents report that additional information may be obtained by contacting Luis Sanchez-Fernandez, University of Seville, Dept Ingn Aerosp & Mecan Fluidos, Area Ingn Agroforestal, Ctra Sevilla Utrera Km 1, Seville 41013, Spain. Additional authors for this research include Manuel Perez-Ruiz, Elena Alonso, Amaya Ortiz-Barredo, Santiago Planas de Marti and Luis Asin Jones.
The direct object identifier (DOI) for that additional information is: https://doi.org/10.1016/j.cropro.2025.107164. This DOI is a link to an online electronic document that is either free or for purchase, and can be your direct source for a journal article and its citation.

urn:contentItem:6FMT-V7N3-RRXW-B0N5-00000-00University of Eldoret Reports Findings in Agroforestry (Agroforestry adoption and its influence on soil quality under smallholder maize production systems in western Kenya)2025-04-23T00:00:00Z2025-09-16T06:41:40ZLexisNexisAGRICULTURE - AGROFORESTRYUniversity of Eldoret Reports Findings in Agroforestry (Agroforestry adoption and its influence on soil quality under smallholder maize production systems in western Kenya)


2025 APR 23 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Agriculture Daily -- New research on Agriculture - Agroforestry is the subject of a report. According to news reporting from Eldoret, Kenya, by NewsRx journalists, research stated, "Agroforestry, a sustainable land use practice, was introduced in western Kenya in the early 1990s as a soil fertility replenishment strategy. Since then, the effect of the practice on soil quality has seldom been evidenced."


Funders for this research include RUFORUM, University of Liberia.
The news correspondents obtained a quote from the research from the University of Eldoret, "A study was conducted to assess the impact of agroforestry adoption on soil quality under smallholder maize systems in the region. Soil samples were collected from two land use practices: agroforestry adoption (90) and non-agroforestry adoption (30) at 0-30 cm depth from two locations (Busia and Kakamega counties). Results showed variations in soil characteristics between the study locations. Soils in Kakamega contained higher concentrations of soil organic carbon (SOC), exchangeable cations, and micronutrients. On average, agroforestry adoption significantly (P 0.05) improved soil physicochemical properties. Under agroforestry adoption, bulk density (BD) reduced by 21% (from 1.4 to1.1 g cm-3), while (SOC) increased by 75% (0.8-1.4%), P by 80% (3.0-5.4 mg kg-1), exchangeable K by 256% (0.3-8.0 cmol kg-1), Ca by 100% (1.0-2.0 cmol kg-1), S by 50% (0.2-0.3 mg kg-1), and Cu by 18% (2.8-3.3 mg kg-1). Agroforestry adoption significantly increased K and Cu levels above the critical thresholds of 0.4 cmol kg-1 and 1.0 mg kg-1, respectively, at both locations. Sesbania sesban and Leucaena leucocephala influenced soil BD, pH and P (4.3.-7.0 mg kg -1), exchangeable K (0.4-0.7 cmol kg-1), Mg (0.1-0.2 cmol kg-1), and Mn (13.5-25.2 mg kg-1) at both locations, while Calliandra calothyrsus significantly increased SOC in Kakamega only. These findings highlight the significance of agroforestry in soil fertility management. Furthermore, Sesbania proved to be effective in enhancing the characteristics of soils at both sites, hence, the need for its inclusion in agroforestry extension messages."
According to the news reporters, the research concluded: "Further studies are needed to understand nutrient release mechanisms from agroforestry biomass and their influence on soil characteristics and maize yield in smallholder farming systems."
For more information on this research see: Agroforestry adoption and its influence on soil quality under smallholder maize production systems in western Kenya. PLOS ONE, 2025;20(4). PLOS ONE can be contacted at: Public Library Science, 1160 Battery Street, Ste 100, San Francisco, CA 94111, USA. (Public Library of Science - www.plos.org; PLOS ONE - www.plosone.org)
Our news journalists report that additional information may be obtained by contacting Ruth Njoroge, Dept. of Soil Science, School of Agriculture & Biotechnology, University of Eldoret, Eldoret, Kenya. Additional authors for this research include Henry Tamba Nyuma and Abigael Nekesa Otinga.
The direct object identifier (DOI) for that additional information is: https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pone.0313385. This DOI is a link to an online electronic document that is either free or for purchase, and can be your direct source for a journal article and its citation.
Publisher contact information for the journal PLOS ONE is: Public Library Science, 1160 Battery Street, Ste 100, San Francisco, CA 94111, USA.

urn:contentItem:6G48-0VB3-RXXM-11MT-00000-00Findings on Agroforestry Reported by Investigators at Punjab Agricultural University [Indian Mustard Genotypes Show Varied Response To Sowing Times Under Poplar (<i>populus Deltoides</i> Bartr.) In the Irrigated Agroecosystem of North-western2025-06-25T00:00:00Z2025-09-16T06:41:40ZLexisNexisAGRICULTURE - AGROFORESTRYFindings on Agroforestry Reported by Investigators at Punjab Agricultural University [Indian Mustard Genotypes Show Varied Response To Sowing Times Under Poplar (<i>populus Deltoides</i> Bartr.) In the Irrigated Agroecosystem of North-western


2025 JUN 25 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Food Daily News -- New research on Agriculture - Agroforestry is the subject of a report. According to news reporting out of Punjab, India, by NewsRx editors, research stated, "Oilseed-based agroforestry offers a sustainable alternative to cereal-based intercropping within agroforestry systems. This study aimed to optimize the yield of Indian mustard (Brassica juncea L.) under a poplar (Populus deltoides Bartr.) plantation by adjusting sowing times and selecting suitable genotype."


Financial supporters for this research include Indian Council of Agricultural Research (ICAR), All India Coordinated Research Project on Agroforestry, PAU, Ludhiana.
Our news journalists obtained a quote from the research from Punjab Agricultural University, "The experiment evaluated the interactive effects of growing environments, sowing times, and genotypes on the growth and yield of Indian mustard. The study was conducted in 4- and 5-year-old poplar plantation over two consecutive rabi seasons (2020-2021 and 2021-2022), with trees spaced at 5 m x 4 m. Three Indian mustard genotypes (RCH 1, PHR 126 and PBR 357) were sown at four different times (1st October, 15th October, 1st November, and 15th November) under two growing conditions: open-field and intercropped within the poplar plantation. By the 5th year, the poplar trees had attained an average diameter of 17.9 cm, height of 16.9 m, and crown spread of 18.3 m2. Microclimatic observations revealed higher temperatures (1-1.2 degrees C) under open conditions than poplar canopy, while relative humidity was consistently higher (5.0-5.7%) beneath the poplar canopy. Photosynthetically active radiation within the poplar plantation declined from mid-October until mid-January, followed by a gradual increase. The findings highlighted that the genotype PBR 357, sown on 15th October, achieved the highest growth and yield parameters under poplar canopy. Seed yield was 17.80 and 16.96 q ha-1 in the 4th and 5th years of poplar, respectively. The percentage reduction in seed yield recorded under the 4-year-old poplar canopy was 29.1%, while under the 5-year-old canopy it increased to 34.6%. In contrast, genotype RCH 1 exhibited superior performance as a sole crop compared to PHR 126 and PBR 357."
According to the news editors, the research concluded: "Thus, combining an optimal sowing time with a well-adapted genotype enhances the productivity and sustainability of agroforestry-based cropping systems."
This research has been peer-reviewed.
For more information on this research see: Indian Mustard Genotypes Show Varied Response To Sowing Times Under Poplar (<i>populus Deltoides</i> Bartr.) In the Irrigated Agroecosystem of North-western India. Agroforestry Systems, 2025;99(5). Agroforestry Systems can be contacted at: Springer, Van Godewijckstraat 30, 3311 Gz Dordrecht, Netherlands. (Springer - www.springer.com; Agroforestry Systems - www.springerlink.com/content/0167-4366/)
Our news journalists report that additional information may be obtained by contacting Navneet Kaur, Punjab Agricultural University, Dept. of Forestry and Natural Resources, Ludhiana 141004, Punjab, India. Additional authors for this research include Puneet Kaur, Rishi I. S. Gill, Harmandeep Kaur and Virender Sardana.
The direct object identifier (DOI) for that additional information is: https://doi.org/10.1007/s10457-025-01218-4. This DOI is a link to an online electronic document that is either free or for purchase, and can be your direct source for a journal article and its citation.

urn:contentItem:6GPM-8083-RTKX-B3BH-00000-00Brazil: Minister of Tourism reinforces sustainable tourism allied with the Amazon bioeconomy2025-09-01T00:00:00Z2025-09-16T06:41:40ZLexisNexisBrazil: Minister of Tourism reinforces sustainable tourism allied with the Amazon bioeconomy

Key Highlights:

* The Minister of Tourism, Celso Sabino, visited Tom-Au, Par, to promote sustainable tourism in the Amazon region.

* The visit aimed to integrate initiatives like the Cooperativa Agrcola Mista de Tom-Au (CAMTA) into sustainable tourism, combining environmental conservation, social inclusion, and cultural valuation.

* CAMTA is an international reference in agroforestry practices and has consolidated the Tom-Au Agroforestry System (SAFTA), a model recognized by the FAO/UN and certified as Social Technology.

Original Press Release:

Sept. 1 -- Ministry of Tourism, Government of Brazilissued the following news release:

- Sabino met with representatives of a cooperative in the municipality of Tom-Au, Par, and discussed how the tourism and agricultural sectors can work together to preserve the environment

The Minister of Tourism, Celso Sabino, met this Monday (01.09) with representatives of the Tom-Au Mixed Agricultural Cooperative (CAMTA), in the municipality of Tom-Au, in Par, an international reference in agroforestry practices and an example of how the Amazon can be a protagonist in sustainable development combined with the generation of employment and income.

During the event, the minister highlighted the importance of integrating initiatives like CAMTA into sustainable tourism in the Amazon, strengthening visitor experiences that combine environmental conservation, social inclusion, and cultural appreciation.

"Tourism and agriculture go hand in hand. Sustainable forest development guarantees job and income generation. Sustainability is an essential pillar for demonstrating to the world the importance of environmental preservation. Today, I had the opportunity to speak with workers from the Cooperative, which stands out as a successful example of agroforestry implementation, in addition to generating significant positive impacts on Amazonian communities in the region, through farmer training and the preservation of local cultural practices."

With over 50 years of experience, CAMTA has consolidated the Tom-Au Agroforestry System (SAFTA), a model recognized by the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO/UN) and certified as a Social Technology by the Banco do Brasil Foundation. The initiative combines agricultural and forestry crops, promoting sustainable forest use, preventing deforestation, restoring degraded areas, and strengthening production chains linked to the bioeconomy.

The meeting reinforced the Ministry of Tourism's commitment to fostering projects that combine environmental preservation, community empowerment, and innovation, expanding development opportunities for the Amazon region.

VISIT - During his visit to Tom Au, the minister also visited the Japanese Immigration History Museum in the city, known as the third-largest Japanese colony in Brazil. The museum preserves the memory and contribution of Japanese immigrants to the region's economic, social, and cultural development. During the visit, the minister highlighted the importance of the local historical heritage as a tourist attraction and as a symbol of the integration of cultures that helped shape the municipality's identity.

urn:contentItem:6GKP-5703-RRVS-61PS-00000-00New Agriculture Findings from ICAR - Central Soil Salinity Research Institute Reported (Diverse Land Use Systems Differentially Affect Soil Quality Index In Reclaimed Sodic Soils of Western Indo-gangetic Plains of India)2025-08-27T00:00:00Z2025-09-16T06:41:40ZLexisNexisAGRICULTURENew Agriculture Findings from ICAR - Central Soil Salinity Research Institute Reported (Diverse Land Use Systems Differentially Affect Soil Quality Index In Reclaimed Sodic Soils of Western Indo-gangetic Plains of India)


2025 AUG 27 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Agriculture Daily -- Researchers detail new data in Agriculture. According to news reporting originating from Haryana, India, by NewsRx correspondents, research stated, "The study evaluated five land use systems: (1) conventional agricultural system (LU-CA; puddled transplanted rice succeeded by conventional tilled wheat), (2) partial conservation agriculture system (LU-PCA; zero-tillage direct-seeded rice succeeded by zero-till wheat with 1/3rd crop residue retention), (3) horticultural system (LU-LHS; Litchi plantation), (4) agroforestry system (LU-MAS; Melia trees + wheat intercrop), and (5) plantation system (LU-EPS; eucalyptus plantation) for their impact on soil health in reclaimed sodic soils. Soil samples from four depths (0-15, 15-30, 30-45 and 45-60 cm) were analysed for physico-chemical, and biological properties to develop a soil quality index (SQI)."


Our news editors obtained a quote from the research from ICAR - Central Soil Salinity Research Institute, "Soil bulk density (BD) was highest in the Melia-based agroforestry system, while soil penetration resistance (SPR) was highest under the conventional system. In comparison, the partial conservation agriculture system exhibited the lowest values for both BD and SPR, indicating improved soil physical conditions under this management practice. The eucalyptus-based system exhibited the highest soil organic carbon (SOC), SOC stock, macronutrients (N, P, K), and biological properties (microbial biomass carbon, microbial biomass nitrogen, and alkaline phosphatase). Relative to LU-CA, LU-PCA increased SOC stock by 22.9%. The highest SQI (0.81) was in eucalyptus plantation, followed by lichi-based horticulture (0.58), while conventional system had the lowest (0.17). Higher SQI in EPS and LHS resulted from greater SOC, microbial biomass, and lower pH, BD and SPR, enhancing soil health."
According to the news editors, the research concluded: "Overall, the findings highlight that perennial systems such as eucalyptus plantations and litchi orchards enhance soil health, quality and organic carbon, offering a sustainable land management strategy for reclaimed sodic soils."
This research has been peer-reviewed.
For more information on this research see: Diverse Land Use Systems Differentially Affect Soil Quality Index In Reclaimed Sodic Soils of Western Indo-gangetic Plains of India. Agroforestry Systems, 2025;99(6). Agroforestry Systems can be contacted at: Springer, Van Godewijckstraat 30, 3311 Gz Dordrecht, Netherlands. (Springer - www.springer.com; Agroforestry Systems - www.springerlink.com/content/0167-4366/)
The news editors report that additional information may be obtained by contacting Ram Kishor Fagodiya, ICAR - Central Soil Salinity Research Institute, Karnal 132001, Haryana, India. Additional authors for this research include Renu Kumari, Gargi Sharma, Kamlesh Verma, Raj Kumar, Kailash Prajapat, Arvind Kumar Rai, Rajender Kumar Yadav and Indu Shekhar Thakur.
The direct object identifier (DOI) for that additional information is: https://doi.org/10.1007/s10457-025-01268-8. This DOI is a link to an online electronic document that is either free or for purchase, and can be your direct source for a journal article and its citation.

urn:contentItem:6FP2-32G3-S45M-Y2TX-00000-00Agroforestry in the Cerrado turns profits—returns may lag 11 years2025-04-28T00:00:00Z2025-09-16T06:41:40ZLexisNexisAgroforestry in the Cerrado turns profits—returns may lag 11 yearsCamila Souza Ramos

Agroforestry systems (SAFs) in Brazil’s Cerrado biome (the Brazilian Savanna) can generate financial returns, but producers must wait at least four years to recover their initial investments, and they often depend on a mix of public and private funding to get started. These findings are part of a new study by The Nature Conservancy (TNC), which analyzed three distinct agroforestry projects in the region. The internal rates of return (IRR) ranged from 26% to 79% per year, while payback periods varied between four and 11 years.

Despite this potential, agroforestry remains a rarity in the Cerrado, a biome long dominated by large-scale monoculture.

Properties employing SAFs account for just 7.2% of all rural properties in the region and only 2.2% of the total agricultural area—reflecting the fact that most agroforestry is concentrated on small family farms. In 2017, three-quarters of SAF properties in the Cerrado were under 100 hectares.

That same year, SAFs occupied 2.8 million hectares across the biome. Yet TNC estimates that there is room for growth: 4 million hectares could be restored through agroforestry as part of mandatory legal reserve requirements. If SAFs were extended to degraded pastures that are legally available and agriculturally viable, they could cover another 14.1 million hectares in the Central-West region alone.

TNC’s study concludes that agroforestry can be a profitable use of land in these areas, but only with adequate financial support. All cases reviewed in the study highlight the need to mobilize both public and private resources—ranging from donations and investments to long-term credit lines.

These multiple sources would ensure the availability of resources for both immediate financing needs and the long-term investments that agroforestry systems demand. Diversifying funding sources, the study notes, is essential not only to reduce risk but also to unlock greater access to credit.

Among the cases analyzed was a partnership between Belterra Agroflorestas and the Brazilian Agricultural Research Corporation (Embrapa). Belterra’s model combines perennial species such as baru, pequi, and macaúba with cassava, an annual crop that provides early income to help offset the costs of implementing and managing the SAF until the perennial trees reach maturity.

In this model, the required investment over the first three years totals R$71,667.82 per hectare. The projected IRR stands at 74%, already accounting for a 15% discount rate.

The second case analyzed is the Sistema Agrocerratense Integrado (SACI), a Cerrado-adapted agroforestry system that incorporates native species of various sizes and ages. These systems were implemented in land reform settlements between 2022 and 2023 through initiatives supported by the World Resources Institute (WRI) and WWF-Brazil.

One of the SACI models generates income from a diverse range of crops, including vegetables, baru, pequi, bananas, aroeira-pimenteira, corn, cassava, saffron, ora-pro-nobis, sesame, and guandu beans. A second configuration features native grasses, shrub species like sorghum and crotalaria, and herbaceous crops such as yams and pumpkins, alongside beekeeping activities.

Implementation costs ranged from R$15,000 to R$16,000 per hectare. According to the study, the expected payback period is six years, with an IRR between 14.5% and 15.2%, adjusted for a 10% discount rate.

The third case examined a farm in Cocalinho, Mato Grosso, featuring an agroforestry system integrated with a rotated silvopastoral system (SSP), developed by Rizoma Agro in partnership with Carbon 4412. The agroforestry component includes cacao, baru, and mahogany, along with banana, taperebá, and mombaça grasses—classified as “service species” due to their role in supporting ecosystem health. The SSP involves mahogany, guandu, baru, and taperebá, combined with brachiaria pasture to support a herd of 4,000 cattle.

The implementation costs were R$6,000 per hectare for the agroforestry system and R$6,800 per hectare for the SSP. When both systems are used in tandem, the expected payback period is nine years, with an IRR of 24.14%. The study notes, however, that further analysis is required to assess the economic viability of acquiring farmland specifically for these purposes.

“The success of agroforestry systems depends on structured partnerships with local, regional, and federal stakeholders to address challenges such as seed and seedling supply, product processing and distribution, fire prevention, and technical assistance,” says Natália Leite, who coordinated the study.

Translation: Todd Harkin

urn:contentItem:6FTH-6C83-RV6K-K2C2-00000-00Findings on Agroforestry Reported by Investigators at Federal University Rio Grande do Sul (The Effects of Agroforestry and Conventional Banana Plantations On Multiple Dimensions of Butterfly Diversity In the Atlantic Forest)2025-05-15T00:00:00Z2025-09-16T06:41:40ZLexisNexisAGRICULTURE - AGROFORESTRYFindings on Agroforestry Reported by Investigators at Federal University Rio Grande do Sul (The Effects of Agroforestry and Conventional Banana Plantations On Multiple Dimensions of Butterfly Diversity In the Atlantic Forest)


2025 MAY 15 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Ecology Daily News -- Current study results on Agriculture - Agroforestry have been published. According to news reporting out of Porto Alegre, Brazil, by NewsRx editors, research stated, "Environmental changes, particularly in agriculture, contribute significantly to biodiversity loss, with habitat fragmentation hindering dispersal and reducing biological diversity. Specific land uses can confine evolutionary groups to certain areas, decreasing local genetic and phylogenetic diversity but potentially increasing them at a larger spatial scale."


Funders for this research include IReL Consortium, Natural Environment Research Council (NERC), Conselho Nacional de Desenvolvimento Cientifico e Tecnologico (CNPQ), Higher Education Personnel (CAPES) fellowship, Conselho Nacional de Desenvolvimento Cientifico e Tecnologico (CNPQ), Fundacao de Amparo a Pesquisa do Estado do Goias (FAPEG).
Our news journalists obtained a quote from the research from Federal University Rio Grande do Sul, "Utilising genetic information at the population level, along with richness, phylogenetic and composition data at the community level, offers a comprehensive understanding of agriculture's impact on biodiversity. In this study, we compared the effects of conventional and agroforestry banana plantations on butterflies' dispersal and diversity relative to native forests. Analysing ddRAD genomic data from Heliconius ethilla narcaea at the population level and assessing richness, abundance, phylogenetic and species diversity of the Nymphalidae family at the community level, we found that agroforestry plantations exhibited the highest butterfly abundance and maintained the rarest genetic groups from H. ethilla narcaea. These genetic groups appeared in both native forests and agroforestry areas, more often in native forests, but were absent in conventional plantations despite evidence for extensive genetic dispersal. Regarding species composition, both banana plantations shared similar species but differed from the native forest, which contained a distinct and phylogenetically clustered group of species, possibly due to its unique microhabitat conditions and more complex structure. The presence of the rarest genetic groups in the population and the occurrence of distinct biological species emphasise the critical role of native forests within an anthropogenic landscape."
According to the news editors, the research concluded: "Agroforestry demonstrates the potential to sustain biodiversity alongside food production."
This research has been peer-reviewed.
For more information on this research see: The Effects of Agroforestry and Conventional Banana Plantations On Multiple Dimensions of Butterfly Diversity In the Atlantic Forest. Biodiversity and Conservation, 2025. Biodiversity and Conservation can be contacted at: Springer, Van Godewijckstraat 30, 3311 Gz Dordrecht, Netherlands. (Springer - www.springer.com; Biodiversity and Conservation - www.springerlink.com/content/0960-3115/)

Additional authors for this research include Leandro Duarte, Cristiano A. Iserhard, Gabriel Nakamura and Nicola Nadeau.
The direct object identifier (DOI) for that additional information is: https://doi.org/10.1007/s10531-025-03075-0. This DOI is a link to an online electronic document that is either free or for purchase, and can be your direct source for a journal article and its citation.

urn:contentItem:6GR3-PSD3-S5K1-04TG-00000-00Reports Outline Agriculture Findings from Nanjing Forestry University (Origin and return of lignin in agriculture and forestry: Realizing a closed-loop system for lignin biological activity utilization)2025-09-12T00:00:00Z2025-09-16T06:41:40ZLexisNexisAGRICULTUREReports Outline Agriculture Findings from Nanjing Forestry University (Origin and return of lignin in agriculture and forestry: Realizing a closed-loop system for lignin biological activity utilization)


2025 SEP 12 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Agriculture Daily -- Current study results on Agriculture have been published. According to news originating from Nanjing, People's Republic of China, by NewsRx correspondents, research stated, "Lignin is a biologically active compound that exhibits notable antioxidant, antibacterial, and UV-resistant properties, thereby playing a crucial role in sustainable agroforestry systems. This article provides a comprehensive review of strategies aimed at augmenting the biological activity of lignin, with particular emphasis on its applications in regulating plant growth, controlling pests and diseases, and serving as feed additives."


Our news journalists obtained a quote from the research from Nanjing Forestry University, "The antibacterial properties of lignin present a viable alternative to conventional copper-based pesticides, thereby diminishing the prevalence of plant pests and diseases while fostering ecological sustainability. Additionally, lignin can be utilized as a protective coating material to safeguard wood against fungal degradation. Lignin can also function as a sand-fixing agent to combat desertification, providing both windbreak and vegetation restoration benefits. Using its ultraviolet absorption, biodegradability, antibacterial, and antioxidant features, lignin and its derivatives can be developed into eco-friendly films as substitutes for conventional plastic mulch films."
According to the news editors, the research concluded: "Notwithstanding the encouraging applications of lignin within agroforestry, it is imperative that future research delves deeper into the structure-activity relationship of lignin to fully harness its potential in this field."
This research has been peer-reviewed.
For more information on this research see: Origin and return of lignin in agriculture and forestry: Realizing a closed-loop system for lignin biological activity utilization. urn:contentItem:6GPT-HG53-RS1C-63S1-00000-00Tripura proposes to get a GI tag for Agar tree2025-09-11T00:00:00Z2025-09-16T06:41:40ZLexisNexisTripura proposes to get a GI tag for Agar treeAgartala

Agartala, Sept. 11 -- The Tripura government has also sent a proposal to the centre for a GI tag for Tripura Agar, the main ingredient for manufacturing perfume, a high-value product in Middle East countries, said Agriculture Minister Ratan Lal Nath here today.

He said the Agriculture and Farmers' Welfare Department and Forest Departments have embarked on a plan to establish Agar nurseries by bringing them under agroforestry and to distribute saplings among people free of cost to convert wasteland into Agar trees, ensuring the boost of rural economy.

Addressing a delegation of the All Tripura Agar Wood Association today, Agriculture Minister Ratan Lal Nath said that the state's Agar is in high demand both within the state and outside. The state government is trying to include Agar in agroforestry, which will also help generate GST revenue.

He mentioned that due to Agar cultivation in Kadamtala along the Assam border under North district last year, the state witnessed significant GST revenue.

"Now, farmers are also expressing their desire to cultivate Agar. In the Cabinet, I will also discuss how we can intensify Agar cultivation. The previous government did nothing for the cultivation and promotion of Agar. In 2021, our government formulated the Tripura Agar Wood Policy. Tripura Agar is world famous," Nath said.

urn:contentItem:6GPF-T0S3-RS7J-W0KK-00000-00Researchers at National University Have Published New Data on Sustainability Research (Balancing tree and crop biodiversity and yield in coffee plantations of the Peruvian Amazon: The role of shade and certification as indicators of sustainable ...)2025-09-09T00:00:00Z2025-09-16T06:41:40ZLexisNexisSUSTAINABILITY RESEARCHResearchers at National University Have Published New Data on Sustainability Research (Balancing tree and crop biodiversity and yield in coffee plantations of the Peruvian Amazon: The role of shade and certification as indicators of sustainable ...)


2025 SEP 09 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Economics Daily Report -- Research findings on sustainability research are discussed in a new report. According to news reporting from National University by NewsRx journalists, research stated, "Intensive coffee cultivation in full-sun monocultures is often associated with biodiversity loss. In this context, agroforestry systems are increasingly valued for their ability to reconcile agricultural productivity with environmental conservation, especially in tropical regions."


Our news journalists obtained a quote from the research from National University: "This study evaluated yield, tree and crop diversity, and shade cover across four coffee production systems in northern Peruvian Amazonia: certified shaded, uncertified shaded, certified monoculture, and uncertified monoculture. While no significant differences in average yields were found, shaded systems exhibited greater biodiversity, with the certified shaded system showing the highest values. However, excessive crop diversification was negatively associated with yield, particularly in certified farms. Shade cover was positively correlated with tree species richness, suggesting an optimal range of 30-50 % to balance productivity and ecosystem services. Certification was not consistently linked to higher biodiversity, raising questions about its effectiveness and implementation. Findings highlight the viability of shaded agroforestry systems in achieving ecological and economic goals."
According to the news reporters, the research concluded: "We recommend promoting certification schemes with quantifiable biodiversity indicators, providing technical assistance, and establishing incentives to maintain adequate shade cover and species diversity. These strategies can enhance farm resilience, conserve critical habitats, and support sustainable development in coffee-growing landscapes of the Amazon."
For more information on this research see: Balancing tree and crop biodiversity and yield in coffee plantations of the Peruvian Amazon: The role of shade and certification as indicators of sustainable management. Environmental Challenges, 2025,20():101223. The publisher for Environmental Challenges is Elsevier.
A free version of this journal article is available at https://doi.org/10.1016/j.envc.2025.101223.

Additional authors for this research include Gerlin Milquito Lopez, Grobert Guadalupe, Ligia Garcia.
